newsitem.title: USA: US Supreme Court clears way for execution.
newsitem.headline: US Supreme Court clears way for execution.

text.p: The Supreme Court cleared the way Friday for the execution of murderer Gary Heidnik, who is now scheduled to die early Saturday morning.
The justices granted by a 5-to-4 vote a last-minute emergency request by the Philadelphia District attorney's office to lift a stay of execution that had been granted by a U.S. Appeals Court.

A spokesman for Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Ridge said Heidnik will be executed by lethal injection at 2 a.m. Saturday in Rockview state prison. He would be the third person to die in Pennsylvania since the state reinstated the death penalty.
The prosecutor's appeal was aimed at setting aside an order that prevented the state from executing Heidnik, 53, for two sadistic murders a decade ago.
Heidnik, who has spent 10 years on death row for kidnapping and torturing six women, killing two of them, was scheduled to die last Tuesday night.

The appeals court opinion, which was set aside by the Supreme Court's ruling, found Heidnik incapable of making a rational decison on his legal rights. The appeals court decision would have blocked his execution and enabled lawyers to reopen the case.

Heidnik claimed insanity at his 1988 trial but a jury convicted him and sentenced him to death. Police arrested Heidnik after a woman escaped from his North Philadelphia rowhouse in 1987, saying he shackled her and five other women in a cellar converted to a torture chamber.
He dismembered one woman, who died of starvation, and fed some of her remains to the others. He killed a second woman by attaching live wires to her chains while she stood in a pit filled with water.
Police found body parts in Heidnik's freezer that belonged to the woman he dismembered. The second victim's body was found dumped in a state forest in New Jersey.
